Hi,

On 3 August 2010 16:14, khasurashai <kyeashke@...> wrote:

> I hope someone might be able to help me here.

SharpNEAt author here. Will endeavour to help.

> I'm managing the evaluations of the genomes outside of Neat entirely, and updating the
> fitness explicitly after each evaluation cycle, before calling
> EvolutionAlgorithm::PerformOneGeneration.

This /might/ be a problem (not 100% sure). Certainly the algorithm as
it is will call the genome evaluator from within
PerformOneGeneration(), by doing it before this method you've
potentially produced a subtle bug.  I would advise that you plug-in
your external evaluation routine via the IGenomeListEvaulator
interface provided - unless there is some particular issue that
prevents this?



> I'm getting situations where I have species with only one member, and the roulette
> selection returns no genome to use for asexual reproduction, because the selection value
> is higher than the fitness of the single member.

To help identify which bit or bits of code you're referring to could I
ask that you point me at particular line numbers.


> I've been backtracking through the code, and I think I've found where the problem arises:
> under EvolutionAlgorithm::PerformOneGeneration, the fitness stats are only updated if
> species have been removed from the population. If species haven't been removed, then
> offspring are created /before/ the fitnesses are updated.

My hunch would be that you've 'broken' the later stages of
PerformOneGeneration() as they rely heavily on the calculated stats.
The flow of calculations in PerformOneGeneration() is ordered very
precicely as there were many chicken and egg type issues that occured
while writing and testing the code (some fairly subtle ones were
reported to me by others even after many rethinks and re-writes of
various sections during the initial authoring)

If you can plug-in an IGenomeListEvaulator that would be a good start
- if not then I'd be interested what problem is present there and we
can take it from there.

Hope that helps a bit,

Colin.
